. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1873 UNRAVELLING E-EVIDENCE: THE ROLE OF CYBER FORENSICS IN DIGITAL INVESTIGATIONS Dr. Munish Swaroop & Mr. Nikhil Bajpai, Assistant Professor, ICFAI Law School, IFHE, Hyderabad, Telangana ABSTRACT The digital era has fundamentally altered how crimes are investigated and evidence is presented in legal proceedings. The proliferation of technology and widespread internet usage has made electronic evidence (E-Evidence) and Cyber Forensics pivotal in combatting cybercrimes. This shift presents a significant challenge for law enforcement and legal professionals as cyber criminals exploit the virtual landscape for illicit activities. E-Evidence encompasses a broad spectrum of digital data, such as emails, instant messages, social media interactions, cloud storage, and browsing history. Cyber Forensics involves the scientific examination and analysis of this digital evidence to unravel cybercrimes. This paper delves into the core principles of Cyber Forensics, including the identification, preservation, extraction, and analysis of digital evidence while ensuring its integrity and admissibility in court. Despite cybercriminals attempting to conceal their digital footprints, forensic investigators employ tools and methodologies to trace events and identify perpetrators. Additionally, the paper explores legal challenges and ethical dilemmas surrounding E-Evidence and Cyber Forensics. Privacy concerns, maintaining chain of custody, and adhering to data protection laws significantly impact the admissibility and trustworthiness of digital evidence in court. The evolving technological landscape necessitates continual updates to legal frameworks to accommodate digital investigations. E-Evidence and Cyber Forensic techniques are indispensable in combatting cybercrimes. As cyber threats evolve, ongoing research and innovation in this field are crucial. Integrating technology, law, and forensics effectively empowers society to proactively tackle cybercriminal activities, safeguard the virtual realm's integrity, and uphold justice in the digital age. Keywords: E-Evidence, Cyber Forensics, Digital Investigations, Cybercrimes, Technological Advancements.

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1874 INTRODUCTION The rapid expansion of Information Technology (IT) has significantly permeated all aspects of our lives, both personally and professionally. However, this relentless pursuit of technological advancements has also given rise to various societal challenges. The constant drive for progress has led to the emergence of new dimensions in criminal activities, altering the landscape of crime. When we contemplate the term 'Computer', it conjures images of the internet, technology, and virtual worlds. This encompasses a wide array of elements for professionals such as lawyers or technicians, including computers, networks, data storage devices, software, mobile phones, and ATMs. All these components fall within the realm of 'cyberspace'—a collective term encompassing anything related to technology or connected to the broader concept of 'computers' and their derivatives. The utilization of sophisticated technologies by criminals has made their activities intricate and challenging to apprehend. Understanding and tracing the origins of these technologically-driven crimes demand a level of proficiency in this field that exceeds the conventional understanding. In recent years, the term 'cybercrime' has emerged, denoting crimes where a computer, either as a tool or a target, plays a central role. Evidence presented in such cases is often in electronic format. However, without the testimony of an expert witness, doubts about the reliability of this evidence can arise. This is where the pivotal role of cyber forensics becomes evident. Forensics, when associated with cyberspace, refers to employing scientific and technological methods within legal proceedings to establish factual evidence. In essence, cyber forensics deals with the collection, preservation, analysis, and presentation of computer-related evidence in a court of law, often termed as "electronic evidence." By integrating scientific methodologies with the technological landscape, cyber forensics bridges the gap between criminal activities conducted through technology and the judicial system. Its application is vital in ensuring the authenticity and admissibility of digital evidence in legal proceedings.

Adopting tried-and-tested tools and methodologies, confirmed by experts, becomes crucial to navigate the intricacies of complex evidence accurately. To mitigate errors during evidence collection, it's essential to subject the tools to simulated examinations each time they're utilized. Both the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 and the Information Technology Act, 2000 provide legal recognition to digital records and evidence submitted in the form of electronic data. As per Section 2(t) of the Information Technology Act, 20001, "electronic record" refers to data, record, or information generated, image or sound stored, received, or sent in electronic form or through microfilm or computer-generated microfiche. The Information Technology Amendment Act, 2008, defines a "communication device" under Section 2(ha)2 as a mobile phone, personal digital assistant, or a combination thereof used for transmitting text, video, audio, or images. One significant change introduced in the evidence law through the Information Technology Act was the acknowledgment of digital documents as evidence. Although the definition of the term "document" under section 3 of the Indian Evidence Act does not explicitly include a digital record, it's evident from the amended definition of "evidence" that documents encompass digital records. Therefore, any information in electronic form—be it text, images, internet records, or phone logs—is considered an electronic record and qualifies as "evidence" for the purposes of the Indian Evidence Act. For instance, if individual A threatens individual B over the phone and this conversation is recorded by B on his mobile phone, this recording becomes a piece of evidence. In this scenario, the court can inspect B's mobile phone containing the voice recording or a transcript of the recorded communication as evidence. Regarding technological advancements, the Supreme Court, in R.M. Malkani v. State of Maharashtra3, deemed tape-recorded communication admissible as evidence. The admissibility criteria include relevance to the matter in question, identification of the voices, and ensuring the accuracy of the communication by safeguarding against any tampering or erasure of the recording. A contemporary tape recording of a relevant conversation is considered admissible evidence under Section 7 of the Indian Evidence Act4, similar to the admissibility of a photograph depicting a relevant incident. 1 Sec 2(t) ,Information Technology Act, 2000 2 Sec 2(ha) ,Information Technology Act, 2000 3 1973 AIR 157 4 Sec 7, The Indian Evidence Act,1872

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1878 The Supreme Court has established specific conditions for the admissibility of voice recordings in conversations: 1. Identification of Speaker's Voice: The person who made the recording or others who recognize the speaker's voice should identify it. In cases where the maker can't identify the voice, stringent proof is necessary to establish it as the alleged speaker's voice. 2. Verification of Accuracy: The maker of the recording must prove the accuracy of the recorded statement through high-quality evidence, either direct or circumstantial. 3. Prevention of Tampering or Erasure: Any possibility of tampering or erasure of the recorded statement must be completely excluded to ensure its integrity. 4. Relevance: The recorded statement must be relevant to the matter under consideration. 5. Secure Custody of Recording: The recorded cassette, compact disk, mobile phone, data card, etc., should be sealed and kept in safe and reliable custody. 6. Clarity and Audibility: The voice of the specific speaker should be clear and not distorted or overshadowed by other sounds or disturbances. However, it's crucial to note that these conditions for admissibility of tape-recorded conversations were established before the Information Technology Act (ITA). It's essential to interpret these conditions in the context of the time they were laid down and to consider how the landscape might have evolved post the ITA. Furthermore, when it comes to electronic records, it's important to understand that their contents cannot be proven through oral evidence. Instead, they can be proved using either primary or secondary evidence. According to Section 64 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)5, documents, including electronic records, must primarily be proved. However, Section 65 of the IEA6 allows for secondary proof of the contents of a document, including electronic records, in certain circumstances as specified. 5 Sec 64, The Indian Evidence Act,1872 6 Sec 65, The Indian Evidence Act,1872

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1879 Sections 64 and 65 of the IEA7 emphasize the fundamental rule of evidence, stating that the best evidence available in the circumstances should be presented to prove a fact in question. These sections provide guidance on how documents, including electronic records, should be proven and admitted as evidence in legal proceedings. It has been established by the Supreme Court in the case of State (NCT of Delhi) v. Navjot Sandhu (also known as the Parliament attack case) that call records from mobile phones are admissible as evidence under section 7 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA). There is no specific prohibition against admitting call records of telephones or mobiles. The court also ruled that it's not always necessary to present examining experts to prove the authenticity of calls made through phones or mobiles. In this case, the Supreme Court further affirmed that secondary evidence of such calls can be presented under Sections 63 & 65 of the IEA. The entire conspiracy theory presented in the Parliament attack case was based on intercepted call records of the accused individuals. Initially, an argument was made on behalf of the accused that the prosecution couldn't rely on the mobile phone call records due to the absence of the relevant certificate under section 65B (4) of the IEA8. However, the Supreme Court concluded that a cross-examination of a competent witness familiar with the functioning of the computer during the relevant time period, including how the printouts of the call records were obtained, was sufficient to establish the reliability and authenticity of the call records as evidence. The court emphasized that the testimony of an expert witness wasn't mandatory to establish the admissibility of call records in such cases. Certainly, the Supreme Court did not address Sections 65A and 65B9 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) concerning the admissibility of digital data in the N.C.T of Delhi v/s Navjot Sandhu10 mentioned earlier. However, in the case of R.K. Anand v. Specifically, it dealt with a situation where a microchip was preserved by a well-known television channel studio, leading the court to believe that the recording could not have been tampered with. The procedure for admitting a CD as evidence was considered in the Re-Ramlila Maidan Incident Dt ... vs Home Secretary And Ors12. Here, the court directed the submission of a CD containing a recording, accompanied by an affidavit as required under Section 65B of the IEA. The court accepted an affidavit from the trustee confirming that the CD had not been tampered with, and subsequently, the CD was taken on record. In numerous cases, courts have refused to attribute probative value to digital data if it does not comply with Section 65B of the IEA. This section outlines specific conditions that need to be fulfilled for the admissibility of electronic evidence, especially recordings, in court. These conditions include certification and verification regarding the integrity of the electronic record, ensuring its authenticity and correctness. If digital data doesn't adhere to these provisions, courts might deny its admissibility or probative value in legal proceedings. Judiciary trend on E-Evidence admissibility In the recent landmark case of Anvar P.V. v. P.K. Basheer13 (referred to as the "Anvar Case"), the Supreme Court took the opportunity to clarify the law concerning the admissibility of digital evidence in judicial proceedings. The case revolved around the assembly elections in Kerala in 2011, where the appellant contested the election results, alleging corrupt practices under Section 100(1)(b) read with Sections 123(2)(ii) and (4) of The Representation of the People Act, 1951. Having lost the appeal in the high court, the appellants appealed to the apex court. The evidence presented in the case consisted of three elements: digital data, documentary evidence other than digital data, and oral evidence. As the main focus of arguments was on electronic evidence, the court addressed this aspect first. 12 SUO MOTU WRIT PETITION (CRL.) NO. 122 OF 2011 13 AIR 2015 SC 180

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1881 The Supreme Court recognized the relevance of various sections of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA), including sections 3, 22A, 45A, 59, 65A, and notably, Section 65B concerning the admissibility of electronic evidence. The court emphasized that any documentary evidence in the form of an electronic record, as per sections 59 and 65A of the IEA, can only be proved in accordance with the procedure prescribed under Section 65B. Section 65B14 specifically deals with the admissibility of electronic evidence. The court highlighted that its purpose is to authenticate secondary evidence in electronic form produced by a computer. Notably, the section begins with a non obstante clause, meaning that despite anything contrary in the Evidence Act, any information contained in an electronic record produced by a computer shall be considered a document only if the conditions under Sub- section (2) of Section 65B are satisfied. The admissibility of such electronic records, known as computer output, hinges on meeting the four conditions specified under Section 65B(2). These conditions play a crucial role in determining the admissibility of electronic records in legal proceedings without the need for further evidence or production of the original. Under Section 65B(2) of the Evidence Act, the following conditions are necessary for admitting a digital record as evidence: (i) The electronic record containing the information should have been generated by the computer used during a period over which it was regularly employed for storing or processing data for an activity routinely conducted by the person having lawful control over the computer. (ii) The data of the type included in the electronic record or from which it is derived should have been consistently inputted into the computer during the regular course of that activity. (iii) Throughout the relevant period, the computer should have been operating properly, and any disruptions or damage should not have affected the accuracy or integrity of the record. (iv) The data in the electronic record should be a reproduction or derived from the information fed into the computer during the usual course of the activity. The Supreme Court has unequivocally stated that the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) doesn't allow the proof of a digital record through oral evidence if the requirements under Section 65B of the IEA are not met. This stance effectively overrules the approach taken in the Parliament attack case. 14 Sec 65B, The Indian Evidence Act,1872

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1882 In a subsequent case, SanjaySinh Ramrao Chavan v. Dattatray Gulabrao Phalke, where evidence of demanding a bribe was sought to be proved using a tape-recorded conversation, the Supreme Court found the evidence inadmissible. The Directorate of Forensic Science Laboratories, State of Maharashtra, reported that the conversation was inaudible and thus was not suitable for spectrographic analysis. The counsel for the respondents argued that the conversation was translated and authenticated by the panch witnesses. However, these panch witnesses had not actually heard the conversation as they were not present in the room. The Supreme Court emphasized that since the voice recording itself wasn't subjected to analysis and the translated version lacked authenticity, relying on the translated version without a credible source for its authenticity was unwarranted. Reiterating the decision in the Anvar case, the Supreme Court stressed the significance of source and authenticity as critical elements for admitting digital evidence. In the case of Ram Kishan Fauji v. State of Haryana15, the Punjab and Haryana High Court dealt with electronic evidence in the form of a CD, considered an electronic record as defined under the Information Technology Act (ITA). The court highlighted the absence of a feasible link between the digital evidence storage media, specifically the CD, and the memory chip presumed to be the source for replicating the data on the CD, as mentioned in the laboratory report. The court emphasized that if the CD could not substantiate its authenticity by being compared with its hash value or any source from which it purportedly derived the data, then the transcript of the audio or video content on the CD could not be considered valuable or admissible as evidence. This ruling underscores the importance of establishing a reliable and authentic link between the storage media and the source of the electronic data, especially when presenting it as evidence in legal proceedings. Without such a link and without verification methods such as comparing hash values, the authenticity and reliability of the digital evidence, such as the content on the CD, may come into question and might not be accepted as credible evidence in court16. 15 CIVIL APPEAL NO. 4288 OF 2017 16 S. K. Verma, Raman Mittal, Legal Dimension of Cyberspace, Indian Law Institute, New Delhi.

. text: Indian Journal of Law and Legal Research Volume VI Issue I | ISSN: 2582-8878 Page: 1883 Cyber Forensic and E-Evidence Cyber forensics stands as a critical discipline within the realm of digital investigations, focusing on the meticulous collection, analysis, and preservation of electronic evidence to combat cybercrimes effectively. As our world increasingly digitizes, the significance of cyber forensics in uncovering and prosecuting cybercrimes has risen exponentially. This discipline revolves around the concept of electronic evidence (e-evidence), encompassing all forms of digital information admissible in legal proceedings, spanning data from computers, networks, mobile devices, cloud services, and more17. The intersection between cyber forensics and e-evidence is profound, serving as the cornerstone in uncovering facts associated with cybercrimes. Let's delve into the intricate relationship between these two domains: 1. Collection and Preservation: Cyber forensics revolves around the meticulous collection and preservation of e-evidence to uphold its integrity and admissibility in court. Just like traditional crime scenes require careful handling, digital crime scenes demand equal care. Cyber forensics specialists employ specialized techniques to secure electronic data without altering its original state, preventing data tampering or spoliation, ensuring its reliability. 2. Data Recovery: Cyber forensics techniques are crucial in recovering data from diverse sources like hard drives, solid-state drives, and memory cards, often intentionally deleted, hidden, or corrupted. Advanced software and methodologies aid in data recovery, significantly contributing to building a case. 3. Analysis: Extracted e-evidence undergoes meticulous analysis employing various tools and techniques to examine log files, metadata, and system artifacts. This analysis unveils insights into cybercriminal activities, methods, and potential motives. 4. Attribution: Identifying the origin and identity of cybercriminals is intricate. ensuring its integrity and admissibility in court. Despite cybercriminals 
attempting to conceal their digital footprints, forensic investigators employ

updates to legal frameworks to accommodate digital investigations.

cybercrimes. As cyber threats evolve, ongoing research and innovation in 
this field are crucial. Integrating technology, law, and forensics effectively

INTRODUCTION 
The rapid expansion of Information Technology (IT) has significantly permeated all 
aspects of our lives, both personally and professionally. However, this relentless pursuit of 
technological advancements has also given rise to various societal challenges. The constant 
drive for progress has led to the emergence of new dimensions in criminal activities, altering 
the landscape of crime. 
When we contemplate the term 'Computer', it conjures images of the internet, 
technology, and virtual worlds. This encompasses a wide array of elements for professionals 
such as lawyers or technicians, including computers, networks, data storage devices, software, 
mobile phones, and ATMs. All these components fall within the realm of 'cyberspace'—a 
collective term encompassing anything related to technology or connected to the broader 
concept of 'computers' and their derivatives. 
The utilization of sophisticated technologies by criminals has made their activities 
intricate and challenging to apprehend. Understanding and tracing the origins of these 
technologically-driven crimes demand a level of proficiency in this field that exceeds the 
conventional understanding. 
In recent years, the term 'cybercrime' has emerged, denoting crimes where a computer, 
either as a tool or a target, plays a central role. Evidence presented in such cases is often in 
electronic format. However, without the testimony of an expert witness, doubts about the 
reliability of this evidence can arise. 
This is where the pivotal role of cyber forensics becomes evident. Forensics, when 
associated with cyberspace, refers to employing scientific and technological methods within 
legal proceedings to establish factual evidence. In essence, cyber forensics deals with the 
collection, preservation, analysis, and presentation of computer-related evidence in a court of 
law, often termed as "electronic evidence." 
By integrating scientific methodologies with the technological landscape, cyber 
forensics bridges the gap between criminal activities conducted through technology and the 
judicial system. Its application is vital in ensuring the authenticity and admissibility of digital 
evidence in legal proceedings.

Navigating E-Evidence: Care and Caution 
Understanding the intrinsic nature of electronic evidence holds tremendous 
significance, as it differs significantly from other forms of evidence. Manipulating electronic 
evidence is relatively easier, especially for experts regularly dealing with it. Hence, managing 
these intricate pieces of evidence requires exceptional care and caution. 
Viruses, Electromagnetic Fields (EMFs), and physical damage stand as primary threats 
to electronic evidence. Adopting tried-and-tested tools and methodologies, confirmed by 
experts, becomes crucial to navigate the intricacies of complex evidence accurately. To mitigate 
errors during evidence collection, it's essential to subject the tools to simulated examinations 
each time they're utilized. 
Preserving the integrity of data is paramount, and therefore, experts and novices alike 
should refrain from manipulating sensitive information whenever possible. Adhering strictly to 
these fundamental practices can bring about a significant transformation in ensuring the 
successful conclusion of legal proceedings. 
Understanding the Legal Landscape: Federal Law on Evidence 
To ensure the admissibility of 'electronic evidence,' adherence to the 'best evidence rule' 
and 'chain of custody' is essential to mitigate any suspicion of tampering. The ideal evidence is 
considered to be in its original form, with printouts or outputs accepted as originals if they 
accurately reflect the information stored in a computer or similar device. 
A framework for admitting electronically admissible evidence is outlined in the Lorraine 
model. It emphasizes several key considerations: 
1. Relevance: The evidence must have the potential to make a fact relevant to the case 
more or less probable than it would be without such evidence. 
2. Authenticity: It's crucial to establish beyond doubt that the electronic evidence 
presented is indeed what it claims to be, as electronic data can be easily altered. 
Thorough authentication is necessary to ensure its credibility.

As per Section 2(t) of the Information Technology Act, 20001, "electronic record" refers 
to data, record, or information generated, image or sound stored, received, or sent in electronic 
form or through microfilm or computer-generated microfiche. The Information Technology 
Amendment Act, 2008, defines a "communication device" under Section 2(ha)2 as a mobile 
phone, personal digital assistant, or a combination thereof used for transmitting text, video, 
audio, or images. 
One significant change introduced in the evidence law through the Information 
Technology Act was the acknowledgment of digital documents as evidence. Although the 
definition of the term "document" under section 3 of the Indian Evidence Act does not explicitly 
include a digital record, it's evident from the amended definition of "evidence" that documents 
encompass digital records. 
Therefore, any information in electronic form—be it text, images, internet records, or 
phone logs—is considered an electronic record and qualifies as "evidence" for the purposes of 
the Indian Evidence Act. For instance, if individual A threatens individual B over the phone 
and this conversation is recorded by B on his mobile phone, this recording becomes a piece of 
evidence. In this scenario, the court can inspect B's mobile phone containing the voice 
recording or a transcript of the recorded communication as evidence. 
Regarding technological advancements, the Supreme Court, in R.M. Malkani v. State 
of Maharashtra3, deemed tape-recorded communication admissible as evidence. The 
admissibility criteria include relevance to the matter in question, identification of the voices, 
and ensuring the accuracy of the communication by safeguarding against any tampering or 
erasure of the recording. A contemporary tape recording of a relevant conversation is 
considered admissible evidence under Section 7 of the Indian Evidence Act4, similar to the 
admissibility of a photograph depicting a relevant incident.

The Supreme Court has established specific conditions for the admissibility of voice 
recordings in conversations: 
1. Identification of Speaker's Voice: The person who made the recording or others who 
recognize the speaker's voice should identify it. In cases where the maker can't identify 
the voice, stringent proof is necessary to establish it as the alleged speaker's voice. 
2. Verification of Accuracy: The maker of the recording must prove the accuracy of the 
recorded statement through high-quality evidence, either direct or circumstantial. 
3. Prevention of Tampering or Erasure: Any possibility of tampering or erasure of the 
recorded statement must be completely excluded to ensure its integrity. 
4. Relevance: The recorded statement must be relevant to the matter under consideration. 
5. Secure Custody of Recording: The recorded cassette, compact disk, mobile phone, 
data card, etc., should be sealed and kept in safe and reliable custody. 
6. Clarity and Audibility: The voice of the specific speaker should be clear and not 
distorted or overshadowed by other sounds or disturbances. 
However, it's crucial to note that these conditions for admissibility of tape-recorded 
conversations were established before the Information Technology Act (ITA). It's essential to 
interpret these conditions in the context of the time they were laid down and to consider how 
the landscape might have evolved post the ITA. 
Furthermore, when it comes to electronic records, it's important to understand that their 
contents cannot be proven through oral evidence. Instead, they can be proved using either 
primary or secondary evidence. According to Section 64 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)5, 
documents, including electronic records, must primarily be proved. However, Section 65 of the 
IEA6 allows for secondary proof of the contents of a document, including electronic records, 
in certain circumstances as specified.

Sections 64 and 65 of the IEA7 emphasize the fundamental rule of evidence, stating that 
the best evidence available in the circumstances should be presented to prove a fact in question. 
These sections provide guidance on how documents, including electronic records, should be 
proven and admitted as evidence in legal proceedings. 
It has been established by the Supreme Court in the case of State (NCT of Delhi) v. 
Navjot Sandhu (also known as the Parliament attack case) that call records from mobile phones 
are admissible as evidence under section 7 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA). There is no 
specific prohibition against admitting call records of telephones or mobiles. The court also 
ruled that it's not always necessary to present examining experts to prove the authenticity of 
calls made through phones or mobiles. 
In this case, the Supreme Court further affirmed that secondary evidence of such calls 
can be presented under Sections 63 & 65 of the IEA. The entire conspiracy theory presented in 
the Parliament attack case was based on intercepted call records of the accused individuals. 
Initially, an argument was made on behalf of the accused that the prosecution couldn't rely on 
the mobile phone call records due to the absence of the relevant certificate under section 65B 
(4) of the IEA8. 
However, the Supreme Court concluded that a cross-examination of a competent 
witness familiar with the functioning of the computer during the relevant time period, including 
how the printouts of the call records were obtained, was sufficient to establish the reliability 
and authenticity of the call records as evidence. The court emphasized that the testimony of an 
expert witness wasn't mandatory to establish the admissibility of call records in such cases. 
Certainly, the Supreme Court did not address Sections 65A and 65B9 of the Indian 
Evidence Act (IEA) concerning the admissibility of digital data in the N.C.T of Delhi v/s Navjot 
Sandhu10 mentioned earlier. However, in the case of R.K. Anand v. Delhi High Court11, the 
Supreme Court was deliberating on the admissibility of recordings stored on microchips and 
CDs.

The Supreme Court recognized the relevance of various sections of the Indian Evidence 
Act (IEA), including sections 3, 22A, 45A, 59, 65A, and notably, Section 65B concerning the 
admissibility of electronic evidence. The court emphasized that any documentary evidence in 
the form of an electronic record, as per sections 59 and 65A of the IEA, can only be proved in 
accordance with the procedure prescribed under Section 65B. 
Section 65B14 specifically deals with the admissibility of electronic evidence. The court 
highlighted that its purpose is to authenticate secondary evidence in electronic form produced 
by a computer. Notably, the section begins with a non obstante clause, meaning that despite 
anything contrary in the Evidence Act, any information contained in an electronic record 
produced by a computer shall be considered a document only if the conditions under Sub-
section (2) of Section 65B are satisfied. The admissibility of such electronic records, known as 
computer output, hinges on meeting the four conditions specified under Section 65B(2). These 
conditions play a crucial role in determining the admissibility of electronic records in legal 
proceedings without the need for further evidence or production of the original. 
Under Section 65B(2) of the Evidence Act, the following conditions are necessary for 
admitting a digital record as evidence: 
(i) The electronic record containing the information should have been generated by the 
computer used during a period over which it was regularly employed for storing or processing 
data for an activity routinely conducted by the person having lawful control over the computer. 
(ii) The data of the type included in the electronic record or from which it is derived should 
have been consistently inputted into the computer during the regular course of that activity. (iii) 
Throughout the relevant period, the computer should have been operating properly, and any 
disruptions or damage should not have affected the accuracy or integrity of the record. (iv) The 
data in the electronic record should be a reproduction or derived from the information fed into 
the computer during the usual course of the activity. 
The Supreme Court has unequivocally stated that the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) doesn't 
allow the proof of a digital record through oral evidence if the requirements under Section 65B 
of the IEA are not met. This stance effectively overrules the approach taken in the Parliament 
attack case.

In a subsequent case, SanjaySinh Ramrao Chavan v. Dattatray Gulabrao Phalke, where 
evidence of demanding a bribe was sought to be proved using a tape-recorded conversation, 
the Supreme Court found the evidence inadmissible. The Directorate of Forensic Science 
Laboratories, State of Maharashtra, reported that the conversation was inaudible and thus was 
not suitable for spectrographic analysis. The counsel for the respondents argued that the 
conversation was translated and authenticated by the panch witnesses. However, these panch 
witnesses had not actually heard the conversation as they were not present in the room. 
The Supreme Court emphasized that since the voice recording itself wasn't subjected to 
analysis and the translated version lacked authenticity, relying on the translated version without 
a credible source for its authenticity was unwarranted. Reiterating the decision in the Anvar 
case, the Supreme Court stressed the significance of source and authenticity as critical elements 
for admitting digital evidence. 
In the case of Ram Kishan Fauji v. State of Haryana15, the Punjab and Haryana High 
Court dealt with electronic evidence in the form of a CD, considered an electronic record as 
defined under the Information Technology Act (ITA). The court highlighted the absence of a 
feasible link between the digital evidence storage media, specifically the CD, and the memory 
chip presumed to be the source for replicating the data on the CD, as mentioned in the 
laboratory report. 
The court emphasized that if the CD could not substantiate its authenticity by being 
compared with its hash value or any source from which it purportedly derived the data, then 
the transcript of the audio or video content on the CD could not be considered valuable or 
admissible as evidence. 
This ruling underscores the importance of establishing a reliable and authentic link 
between the storage media and the source of the electronic data, especially when presenting it 
as evidence in legal proceedings. Without such a link and without verification methods such as 
comparing hash values, the authenticity and reliability of the digital evidence, such as the 
content on the CD, may come into question and might not be accepted as credible evidence in 
court16.

When multiple countries are involved in an incident, jurisdictional challenges escalate. 
For example, a cyber-attack might originate from Country A, affect victims' data in Country

and which authorities should lead the investigation becomes a complex issue. 
Discrepancies in legal standards across jurisdictions further complicate cybercrime 
investigations. What might be deemed cybercrime in one country could be considered a 
legitimate activity in another. Additionally, varying levels of technological expertise within 
law enforcement agencies impact their effectiveness in probing cybercrimes, leading to 
differences in investigation quality and thoroughness. 
Preserving and admitting digital evidence in court poses another hurdle. Digital 
evidence is volatile and easily tampered with, especially when stored in different 
jurisdictions. Obtaining evidence in a timely and lawful manner becomes challenging. 
Diverse standards for admitting digital evidence in court create doubts about its authenticity 
and reliability. Maintaining the chain of custody for digital evidence across borders is 
crucial but problematic. 
International cooperation, often facilitated by Mutual Legal Assistance Treaties 
(MLATs), aims to assist investigations and evidence collection. However, bureaucratic 
delays in these processes hinder timely information exchange, allowing cybercriminals to 
evade justice. Political or diplomatic issues may also deter some countries from 
cooperating, providing safe havens for cybercriminals24. 
Anonymizing technologies like Tor and VPNs further complicate matters by masking 
the origin of cyber-attacks. Cybercriminals leverage these technologies to obfuscate their 
location, making it challenging to trace them accurately. Efforts to standardize cybercrime 
legislation and cooperation frameworks, like the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime, aim 
to address these issues, yet gaps persist due to uneven adoption.

INTRODUCTION 
The rapid expansion of Information Technology (IT) has significantly permeated all 
aspects of our lives, both personally and professionally. However, this relentless pursuit of 
technological advancements has also given rise to various societal challenges. The constant 
drive for progress has led to the emergence of new dimensions in criminal activities, altering 
the landscape of crime. 
When we contemplate the term 'Computer', it conjures images of the internet, 
technology, and virtual worlds. This encompasses a wide array of elements for professionals 
such as lawyers or technicians, including computers, networks, data storage devices, software, 
mobile phones, and ATMs. All these components fall within the realm of 'cyberspace'—a 
collective term encompassing anything related to technology or connected to the broader 
concept of 'computers' and their derivatives. 
The utilization of sophisticated technologies by criminals has made their activities 
intricate and challenging to apprehend. Understanding and tracing the origins of these 
technologically-driven crimes demand a level of proficiency in this field that exceeds the 
conventional understanding. 
In recent years, the term 'cybercrime' has emerged, denoting crimes where a computer, 
either as a tool or a target, plays a central role. Evidence presented in such cases is often in 
electronic format. However, without the testimony of an expert witness, doubts about the 
reliability of this evidence can arise. 
This is where the pivotal role of cyber forensics becomes evident. Forensics, when 
associated with cyberspace, refers to employing scientific and technological methods within 
legal proceedings to establish factual evidence. In essence, cyber forensics deals with the 
collection, preservation, analysis, and presentation of computer-related evidence in a court of 
law, often termed as "electronic evidence." 
By integrating scientific methodologies with the technological landscape, cyber 
forensics bridges the gap between criminal activities conducted through technology and the 
judicial system. Its application is vital in ensuring the authenticity and admissibility of digital 
evidence in legal proceedings.

Navigating E-Evidence: Care and Caution 
Understanding the intrinsic nature of electronic evidence holds tremendous 
significance, as it differs significantly from other forms of evidence. Manipulating electronic 
evidence is relatively easier, especially for experts regularly dealing with it. Hence, managing 
these intricate pieces of evidence requires exceptional care and caution. 
Viruses, Electromagnetic Fields (EMFs), and physical damage stand as primary threats 
to electronic evidence. Adopting tried-and-tested tools and methodologies, confirmed by 
experts, becomes crucial to navigate the intricacies of complex evidence accurately. To mitigate 
errors during evidence collection, it's essential to subject the tools to simulated examinations 
each time they're utilized. 
Preserving the integrity of data is paramount, and therefore, experts and novices alike 
should refrain from manipulating sensitive information whenever possible. Adhering strictly to 
these fundamental practices can bring about a significant transformation in ensuring the 
successful conclusion of legal proceedings. 
Understanding the Legal Landscape: Federal Law on Evidence 
To ensure the admissibility of 'electronic evidence,' adherence to the 'best evidence rule' 
and 'chain of custody' is essential to mitigate any suspicion of tampering. The ideal evidence is 
considered to be in its original form, with printouts or outputs accepted as originals if they 
accurately reflect the information stored in a computer or similar device. 
A framework for admitting electronically admissible evidence is outlined in the Lorraine 
model. It emphasizes several key considerations: 
1. Relevance: The evidence must have the potential to make a fact relevant to the case 
more or less probable than it would be without such evidence. 
2. Authenticity: It's crucial to establish beyond doubt that the electronic evidence 
presented is indeed what it claims to be, as electronic data can be easily altered. 
Thorough authentication is necessary to ensure its credibility. 
3. Hearsay: The issue of hearsay needs to be addressed, specifically whether the

5. Balancing Test: Lastly, the potential risks of prejudice, confusion, or undue delay

Logical Relevance: According to Federal rules of evidence, relevant proof is

maintain its admissibility. Courts must ascertain, beyond any doubt, the integrity and

In summary, maintaining the authenticity, relevance, and integrity of electronic evidence is 
imperative to ensure its admissibility in legal proceedings. Courts must rigorously scrutinize 
electronic evidence to maintain the fairness and accuracy of the judicial process.

regulations in cyberspace. It introduced concepts like 'digital signatures,' 'encryption,' and 
'electronic evidence,' which were previously unfamiliar in the law of evidence. Initially, there 
were no provisions to introduce them as evidence in courts.

the Information Technology Act, 2000 provide legal recognition to digital records and evidence 
submitted in the form of electronic data. 
As per Section 2(t) of the Information Technology Act, 20001, "electronic record" refers 
to data, record, or information generated, image or sound stored, received, or sent in electronic 
form or through microfilm or computer-generated microfiche. The Information Technology 
Amendment Act, 2008, defines a "communication device" under Section 2(ha)2 as a mobile 
phone, personal digital assistant, or a combination thereof used for transmitting text, video, 
audio, or images. 
One significant change introduced in the evidence law through the Information 
Technology Act was the acknowledgment of digital documents as evidence. Although the 
definition of the term "document" under section 3 of the Indian Evidence Act does not explicitly 
include a digital record, it's evident from the amended definition of "evidence" that documents 
encompass digital records. 
Therefore, any information in electronic form—be it text, images, internet records, or 
phone logs—is considered an electronic record and qualifies as "evidence" for the purposes of 
the Indian Evidence Act. For instance, if individual A threatens individual B over the phone 
and this conversation is recorded by B on his mobile phone, this recording becomes a piece of 
evidence. In this scenario, the court can inspect B's mobile phone containing the voice 
recording or a transcript of the recorded communication as evidence. 
Regarding technological advancements, the Supreme Court, in R.M. Malkani v. State 
of Maharashtra3, deemed tape-recorded communication admissible as evidence. The 
admissibility criteria include relevance to the matter in question, identification of the voices, 
and ensuring the accuracy of the communication by safeguarding against any tampering or 
erasure of the recording. A contemporary tape recording of a relevant conversation is 
considered admissible evidence under Section 7 of the Indian Evidence Act4, similar to the 
admissibility of a photograph depicting a relevant incident.

The Supreme Court has established specific conditions for the admissibility of voice 
recordings in conversations: 
1. Identification of Speaker's Voice: The person who made the recording or others who 
recognize the speaker's voice should identify it. In cases where the maker can't identify 
the voice, stringent proof is necessary to establish it as the alleged speaker's voice. 
2. Verification of Accuracy: The maker of the recording must prove the accuracy of the 
recorded statement through high-quality evidence, either direct or circumstantial. 
3. Prevention of Tampering or Erasure: Any possibility of tampering or erasure of the 
recorded statement must be completely excluded to ensure its integrity. 
4. Relevance: The recorded statement must be relevant to the matter under consideration. 
5. Secure Custody of Recording: The recorded cassette, compact disk, mobile phone, 
data card, etc., should be sealed and kept in safe and reliable custody. 
6. Clarity and Audibility: The voice of the specific speaker should be clear and not 
distorted or overshadowed by other sounds or disturbances. 
However, it's crucial to note that these conditions for admissibility of tape-recorded 
conversations were established before the Information Technology Act (ITA). It's essential to 
interpret these conditions in the context of the time they were laid down and to consider how 
the landscape might have evolved post the ITA. 
Furthermore, when it comes to electronic records, it's important to understand that their 
contents cannot be proven through oral evidence. Instead, they can be proved using either 
primary or secondary evidence. According to Section 64 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)5, 
documents, including electronic records, must primarily be proved. However, Section 65 of the 
IEA6 allows for secondary proof of the contents of a document, including electronic records, 
in certain circumstances as specified.

witness familiar with the functioning of the computer during the relevant time period, including 
how the printouts of the call records were obtained, was sufficient to establish the reliability 
and authenticity of the call records as evidence. The court emphasized that the testimony of an 
expert witness wasn't mandatory to establish the admissibility of call records in such cases.

The Supreme Court recognized the relevance of various sections of the Indian Evidence 
Act (IEA), including sections 3, 22A, 45A, 59, 65A, and notably, Section 65B concerning the 
admissibility of electronic evidence. The court emphasized that any documentary evidence in 
the form of an electronic record, as per sections 59 and 65A of the IEA, can only be proved in 
accordance with the procedure prescribed under Section 65B. 
Section 65B14 specifically deals with the admissibility of electronic evidence. The court 
highlighted that its purpose is to authenticate secondary evidence in electronic form produced 
by a computer. Notably, the section begins with a non obstante clause, meaning that despite 
anything contrary in the Evidence Act, any information contained in an electronic record 
produced by a computer shall be considered a document only if the conditions under Sub-
section (2) of Section 65B are satisfied. The admissibility of such electronic records, known as 
computer output, hinges on meeting the four conditions specified under Section 65B(2). These 
conditions play a crucial role in determining the admissibility of electronic records in legal 
proceedings without the need for further evidence or production of the original. 
Under Section 65B(2) of the Evidence Act, the following conditions are necessary for 
admitting a digital record as evidence: 
(i) The electronic record containing the information should have been generated by the 
computer used during a period over which it was regularly employed for storing or processing 
data for an activity routinely conducted by the person having lawful control over the computer. 
(ii) The data of the type included in the electronic record or from which it is derived should 
have been consistently inputted into the computer during the regular course of that activity. (iii) 
Throughout the relevant period, the computer should have been operating properly, and any 
disruptions or damage should not have affected the accuracy or integrity of the record. (iv) The 
data in the electronic record should be a reproduction or derived from the information fed into 
the computer during the usual course of the activity. 
The Supreme Court has unequivocally stated that the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) doesn't 
allow the proof of a digital record through oral evidence if the requirements under Section 65B 
of the IEA are not met. This stance effectively overrules the approach taken in the Parliament 
attack case.

In a subsequent case, SanjaySinh Ramrao Chavan v. Dattatray Gulabrao Phalke, where 
evidence of demanding a bribe was sought to be proved using a tape-recorded conversation, 
the Supreme Court found the evidence inadmissible. The Directorate of Forensic Science 
Laboratories, State of Maharashtra, reported that the conversation was inaudible and thus was 
not suitable for spectrographic analysis. The counsel for the respondents argued that the 
conversation was translated and authenticated by the panch witnesses. However, these panch 
witnesses had not actually heard the conversation as they were not present in the room. 
The Supreme Court emphasized that since the voice recording itself wasn't subjected to 
analysis and the translated version lacked authenticity, relying on the translated version without 
a credible source for its authenticity was unwarranted. Reiterating the decision in the Anvar 
case, the Supreme Court stressed the significance of source and authenticity as critical elements 
for admitting digital evidence. 
In the case of Ram Kishan Fauji v. State of Haryana15, the Punjab and Haryana High 
Court dealt with electronic evidence in the form of a CD, considered an electronic record as 
defined under the Information Technology Act (ITA). The court highlighted the absence of a 
feasible link between the digital evidence storage media, specifically the CD, and the memory 
chip presumed to be the source for replicating the data on the CD, as mentioned in the 
laboratory report. 
The court emphasized that if the CD could not substantiate its authenticity by being 
compared with its hash value or any source from which it purportedly derived the data, then 
the transcript of the audio or video content on the CD could not be considered valuable or 
admissible as evidence. 
This ruling underscores the importance of establishing a reliable and authentic link 
between the storage media and the source of the electronic data, especially when presenting it 
as evidence in legal proceedings. Without such a link and without verification methods such as 
comparing hash values, the authenticity and reliability of the digital evidence, such as the 
content on the CD, may come into question and might not be accepted as credible evidence in 
court16.

Cyber Forensic and E-Evidence 
Cyber forensics stands as a critical discipline within the realm of digital investigations, 
focusing on the meticulous collection, analysis, and preservation of electronic evidence to 
combat cybercrimes effectively. As our world increasingly digitizes, the significance of cyber 
forensics in uncovering and prosecuting cybercrimes has risen exponentially. This discipline 
revolves around the concept of electronic evidence (e-evidence), encompassing all forms of 
digital information admissible in legal proceedings, spanning data from computers, networks, 
mobile devices, cloud services, and more17. 
The intersection between cyber forensics and e-evidence is profound, serving as the 
cornerstone in uncovering facts associated with cybercrimes. Let's delve into the intricate 
relationship between these two domains: 
1. Collection and Preservation: Cyber forensics revolves around the meticulous collection 
and preservation of e-evidence to uphold its integrity and admissibility in court. Just 
like traditional crime scenes require careful handling, digital crime scenes demand 
equal care. Cyber forensics specialists employ specialized techniques to secure 
electronic data without altering its original state, preventing data tampering or 
spoliation, ensuring its reliability. 
2. Data Recovery: Cyber forensics techniques are crucial in recovering data from diverse 
sources like hard drives, solid-state drives, and memory cards, often intentionally 
deleted, hidden, or corrupted. Advanced software and methodologies aid in data 
recovery, significantly contributing to building a case. 
3. Analysis: Extracted e-evidence undergoes meticulous analysis employing various tools 
and techniques to examine log files, metadata, and system artifacts. This analysis 
unveils insights into cybercriminal activities, methods, and potential motives. 
4. Attribution: Identifying the origin and identity of cybercriminals is intricate. Cyber 
forensics aids in tracing attacks to their source, analyzing patterns, timestamps, IP

Challenges before Cyber Forensic 
Cyber forensics, or digital forensics, involves the collection, analysis, and preservation of 
digital evidence for investigating cybercrimes. However, this field grapples with several 
software and hardware challenges that can complicate investigations and affect evidence 
reliability. These challenges stem from the fast-paced evolution of technology, encryption 
techniques, privacy concerns, and the massive data volumes generated in the digital era. 
1. Hardware Challenges: 
• 
Physical Device Access: Obtaining access to locked or password-protected 
devices, particularly mobile phones and encrypted hard drives, poses significant 
hurdles for cyber forensic investigations.

When multiple countries are involved in an incident, jurisdictional challenges escalate. 
For example, a cyber-attack might originate from Country A, affect victims' data in Country 
B, and have its infrastructure located in Country C. Determining which country's laws apply 
and which authorities should lead the investigation becomes a complex issue. 
Discrepancies in legal standards across jurisdictions further complicate cybercrime 
investigations. What might be deemed cybercrime in one country could be considered a 
legitimate activity in another. Additionally, varying levels of technological expertise within 
law enforcement agencies impact their effectiveness in probing cybercrimes, leading to 
differences in investigation quality and thoroughness. 
Preserving and admitting digital evidence in court poses another hurdle. Digital 
evidence is volatile and easily tampered with, especially when stored in different 
jurisdictions. Obtaining evidence in a timely and lawful manner becomes challenging. 
Diverse standards for admitting digital evidence in court create doubts about its authenticity 
and reliability. Maintaining the chain of custody for digital evidence across borders is 
crucial but problematic. 
International cooperation, often facilitated by Mutual Legal Assistance Treaties 
(MLATs), aims to assist investigations and evidence collection. However, bureaucratic 
delays in these processes hinder timely information exchange, allowing cybercriminals to 
evade justice. Political or diplomatic issues may also deter some countries from 
cooperating, providing safe havens for cybercriminals24. 
Anonymizing technologies like Tor and VPNs further complicate matters by masking 
the origin of cyber-attacks. Cybercriminals leverage these technologies to obfuscate their 
location, making it challenging to trace them accurately. Efforts to standardize cybercrime 
legislation and cooperation frameworks, like the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime, aim 
to address these issues, yet gaps persist due to uneven adoption.

CONCLUSION  
The synergy between E-Evidence and Cyber Forensics has profoundly transformed how 
the legal system manages digital information. Their interdependent relationship plays a pivotal 
role in identifying and scrutinizing electronic evidence, now an indispensable component of 
legal procedures. Adapting to the dynamic digital landscape necessitates collaboration among 
legal practitioners, law enforcement, and forensic experts. It's crucial to modify methodologies 
in tandem with technological progress while upholding fundamental principles such as 
transparency, integrity, and safeguarding individual rights. 
India's accomplishment in keeping pace with technological advancements through 
significant legislative amendments in response to these changes is commendable for law 
enforcement agencies and lawmakers. However, ensuring adequate training for Implementing 
Authorities to effectively execute these provisions is a critical and immediate need. It's 
anticipated that in the forthcoming years, this issue will be addressed, leading to a revamped, 
modernized, and technologically adept framework of laws and enforcement practices.

. text: FACT FINDING BY THE WORLD COURT What are the fact-finding techniques of the World Court and how well do they work? Although it is somewhat misleading to treat gen- erally the functions of any institution, it may be helpful to view fact gathering by the World Court from the perspective used to examine fruitfully national intelligence systems. Fact gathering is an endless process. Some facts must be avail- able to the fact-finder in the beginning to enable him to appraise his fact-finding task. Who are the fact finders of the World Court? Why are they looking for facts? What facts are they looking for? How is a flow of basic information necessary for the appraisal process main- tained to the Court and the people who appear before it? What legal doctrines condition their access to this information and their use of it ?"6 How are fact-finding missions allocated once the intelligence task is appraised? Whose decisions determine the allocation? To what extent does the allocation of the fact-finding task condition the facts available to the Court for decision? Once the fact-finding task is determined and missions allocated, how is the actual surveillance executed? What legal doctrines deter- mine the facts that will get before the Court and those that will not? Whose decisions determine what facts will be considered and what facts ignored? These are some of the questions that ought to be asked about the fact-finding functions of the World Court. This Article does not pur- port to answer all of them. A judge of the World Court, unlike the judges of many national courts, cannot retire into a cloister to emerge only for the hearing of cases and the reading of decisions. The special environment in which a judge of the World Court must live and work has produced two problems, both of which are related to his effectiveness as a fact finder. What positions can he accept without compromising his position as a judge? Under what circumstances in relation to a particular case is he obliged to step aside because he knows too much about it? The statute of the Court is not particularly helpful in answering either question. Article 17 of the statute sets forth certain grounds of disqualification that seem obvious as well as reasonable. No member of the Court may participate in the decision of any case in which he has previously taken part as agent, counsel or advocate for one of the parties, or as a member of a national or international court, or of a commission of inquiry, or in any other capacity. 2 Any doubt on the point is settled by a decision of the Court. A judge is not disqualified simply because he is a national of a State which is a party before the Court.5" Suppose he is extremely well informed about a case before it reaches the Court. Is he obligated to disqualify himself on this ground only? Is he obligated to disqualify himself if he has reached a tentative opinion as to the proper result? This seems to be a matter primarily for the judge's conscience. Treaties sometimes provide for appointment by the President of the Court of arbitrators, umpires or members of conciliation commissions. Thus, the Treaty of Lausanne provided for appointment of the President of the Mixed Arbitral Tribunals by the President of the Court if the parties could not agree upon a selection. The President performed this function in 1924 by appointing a President for the Greco-Turkish and Romano-Turkish Tribunals. 9 Special requests are sometimes made by States or international organizations for appointments to fill special offices. In 1954 the President nominated a Chairman for a Special Advisory Board appointed by the Secretary-General of the United Nations.7" Requests are also made by corporations to appoint arbi- trators to settle contract disputes and these requests are usually granted. Certain appointments, quite certainly, have no potential value to the Court as information sources.7 But in other instances, such as an appointment of members of a conciliation commission or arbitral board, the appointment could be conditioned upon reports by the member concerned or upon his willingness to testify or produce evidence be- fore the Court if later called upon. The President is usually approached and his consent secured before the treaty provision or special request for appointment is made. . text: VILLANOVA LAW REVIEW ceedings or in the course of oral proceedings".72 His remark applies with equal accuracy to the work of the International Court of Justice. The exclusion of fact in the Anglo-American judicial duel has come to be taken for granted by American judges and lawyers. The burden is on the opponent to produce the facts and, if he can be kept from getting them in, so much the better for the client. The practice has been tolerated not only because of the lawyer's affection for tradi- tion but because the judge does not have the time to set out upon ex- tensive fact-finding inquiries of his own. The judge is an umpire at trial. The judge on appeal tends to accept the facts produced at trial. There is no reason why this situation should exist in cases brought before the World Court. The General List of the Court is not over- crowded and the judges, or at least most of them, are not imbued with Anglo-American legal traditions. Why are the parties allowed to per- form the major fact-finding function before the World Court? Who makes the decisions which determine who finds the facts? The statute of the Court sets forth the major outlines of the fact-finding missions which the Court can pursue. Since the statute is based upon State consent and State consent pervades the entire problem of the Court's jurisdiction, it is understandable that special deference should be shown to the statements made by State repre- sentatives and the facts produced by them. Nevertheless, in spite of the very real obstacle that State consent presents in fact-finding, this single factor cannot explain why the Court has not moved with greater freedom in finding facts within the confines that its statute establishes. Two factors appear to account for the reticence of the Court, particularly in contentious cases, to make independent inquiries. The Court has been prone to regard executive-administrative findings-of- fact as conclusive because of the limitations set by the statute upon its own fact-finding activities. This predisposition has carried over into contentious litigation, the State being treated as an administrative fact-finder whose conclusions must be accepted at face value unless manifestly questionable. Likewise, in the history of the Permanent Court, there were efforts to use the Court as a fact-finding institution for the League and other international organizations. This resulted in resistence within the Court to any extension of judicial fact-finding activity. 72. HUDSON, THE PERMANENT COURT OF INTERNATIONAL JUSTICE (1920-1942) 565 (1943). [VOL. 4: p. 37

. text: FACT FINDING BY THE WORLD COURT A. The Notion of Executive-Administrative Finality. In the Anglo-American and Civil Law judicial systems the theory of finality of administrative and legislative findings-of-fact has been firmly implanted. The theory may be based upon constitutional sepa- ration of powers, upon a need for efficiency in sifting voluminous facts or upon the inability of the Court to appraise remote events. It is understandable that judges trained in the Anglo-American and Civil Law systems should tend to apply these theories to the work of the World Court. There is also more justification for the application of theories of finality when the fact-finding ability of the Court is sub- stantially curtailed. The Court has no processes to compel the pro- duction of evidence. It may request of public international organiza- tions information relative to cases before it,73 and may call upon the agents to produce any document or supply any explanation. 7 4 Relevant questions may be put to witnesses and experts.7 3 But the Court must depend upon the consent of States to produce witnesses or permit the making of inquiries on the spot.76 Requests for advisory opinions must be accompanied by all documents "likely to throw light" upon the question. 77 Lacking the necessary power to compel the production of the evidence it may need, the Court tends to rely heavily upofi the evidence submitted without positive efforts to police the truth of the facts. In the case of The Prince of Pless,7 8 Poland maintained that the German application was inadmissible so long as the Prince had failed to exhaust his administrative remedies in Poland. In the absence of sufficient materials in the dis- cussions and arguments submitted to it, it must abstain from pro- viding concrete solutions for the complex problems which may arise in the application of Article 2 to persons who, though be- longing to one family, do not individually satisfy the conditions laid down in that article. The rest of this article deals with four major problems produced by surveillance practices: procuring and use of testimony by witnesses; use of expert inquiries; rules of evidence; and State security restric- tions. No effort is made to discuss rules of evidence exhaustively since several excellent treatments of this subject are now in print.'45 There have been few contentious cases before the Court in which the parties have disputed the facts. Of these, the Corfu Channel Case sheds more light upon the difficulties of independent inquiry by the Court than any other. The case is a judicial landmark and figures prominently in the subsequent discussion. 146 145. In view of numerous references to this case in the subsequent materials the facts of the case are stated briefly here. On October 22, 1946, two British destroyers, H.M.S. "Saumarez" and H.M.S. "Volage" struck mines while passing through the fairway of the Corfu Channel. These vessels were part of a squadron passing through the Channel subject to secret British orders X.C.U. Upon receipt of the report of the mining, the Central International Mine Clearance Board recommended that the channel be reswept at a favorable opportunity (the channel having been swept prior to October 1946), but stated that the sweeping of the channel remained an issue out- side its scope. The British nevertheless swept the channel on the 12th and 13th of November, 1946 (Operation Retail). A member of the Mediterranean Mine Clearance Board, Commander Mestre, attended the sweeping as an observer. Two German G-Y mines were recovered and taken to Malta for inspection. Diplomatic negotiations with Albania having failed, the British took the case before the Security Council under Article 35 of the Charter. Albania accepted an invitation to attend the Security Council proceedings upon condition of her acceptance, for the purposes of the dispute, of the obligations of a member of the United Nations. The Security Council appointed a subcommittee to investigate the facts, and the report of this committee was con- sidered by the Council. Ultimately, a finding by the Council adverse to Albania was blocked by the veto, but a British resolution referred the case to the World Court. The British brought the case before the Court by application, and Albania raised a preliminary question of jurisdiction on the ground that the case should have been submitted by special agreement. The Court decided that it was unnecessary to pass upon this issue because Albania had voluntarily accepted its jurisdiction by a letter of July 2, 1947. Corfu Channel Case (Preliminary Objection), Judgment of March 25, 1948, [1947-48] I.C.J. Rep. 15. Immediately after this decision the case was submitted by special agreement. The claim of the United Kingdom in this agreement was Albanian responsibility for the explosions and liability for the resulting damages. The British case was that the mines were laid by Yugoslavia with Albanian connivance or that Albania knew the mines had been laid and failed to give notice as required by international law. Albania counterclaimed that the United Kingdom had violated her sovereignty on October 22, 1946, not having been in innocent passage, and had again violated her sovereignty in Operation Retail on the 12th and 13th of November 1946. After hearing witnesses and directing an expert inquiry on the spot, the Court gave judgment for the British on their claim on the ground that Albania knew or should have known of the mining and failed to give warning; the court gave judgment for Albania on that part of her counterclaim pertaining to Operation Retail. The Court determined the indemnity in a separate proceeding in which Albania refused to participate. A second committee of experts was formed to aid the Court in determining the indemnity due. The features which would enhance the effectiveness of the use of testimony will require changes in the statute or the conclusion of a special convention. The Court needs the authority to compel the production of witnesses or at least the States should undertake to enact national laws for the production of needed witnesses and documents. It is also desirable that a witness be given immunity for testimony offered before the Court. Immunity should extend to criminal prose- cution if general immunity cannot be granted. B. Special and Expert Inquiries. The Court may make a special inquiry into facts, including in- vestigations on the spot, in two ways. Members of the Court may be commissioned to make the inquiry. Technical experts may be com- missioned to investigate matters of a type for which their training makes them particularly suitable. The Court has power to create Special Chambers.19' In con- tentious proceedings the use of Chambers requires the consent of the parties. In advisory proceedings, however, the Court could use Chambers as it saw fit." 94 If Chambers were formed for the purpose of investigation, the Chamber could not only investigate but also could decide the case." 95 The regular use of Chambers for this purpose would, in effect, create a supplementary court system. Appeals could not be taken to the World Court, however, without a change in the statute. 6 On one occasion, the Court as a whole conducted an investi- gation on the spot. The experts were to examine specified evidence to render an opinion as to what conclusions could be drawn concerning the type mine that injured the vessels, whether the mines were laid methodically, the purpose for which they were laid and when they were laid. The experts do not appear to have questioned British personnel or to have examined the vessels or stores. It was indicated in the report that the figures determined were an approxi- mation as some of the equipment injured was secret and other equip- ment had to be dismantled before the extent of damage could be de- termined. The experts were examined by the Court at a special sitting. There is no reason to suppose that the technique of expert in- quiries will cease to be used with the Corfu Channel Case. The value of the information obtained from the experts was greater than that of any evidence contributed by witnesses before the Court. The major question is not whether the Court will be prepared to use an expert inquiry on the spot in an appropriate case but whether the States concerned will cooperate in allowing the experts access to information. This is a factor difficult to appraise, but the national official does not live who will refuse to trade information for values deemed of greater advantage to his State. Albania was willing to go before the Court because of her loss of moral prestige in proceedings before the Security Counsel. She was prepared to receive investigators in an effort to regain her position of respect in the Community of States. C. Attitude of the Court Concerning Rules of Evidence. Rules of evidence familiar in the Anglo-American legal system have been rejected outright by the Court or, when received, modified substantially before being applied. . text: FACT FINDING BY THE WORLD COURT to any system of taking evidence, . . . its task is to cooperate in the objective ascertainment of the truth. 223 The Court seems to have reworked the rules of evidence which it does apply with three objects in mind: (1) to bridge the gap left by the non-production of evidence, (2) to enable the Court to weigh the evidence submitted, and (3) to allow the opposing party to meet the evidence introduced. Evidence is seldom excluded by the Court. (1.) Unreasonable Searches and Seizures. The Court appears to accept evidence no matter how it was obtained by the party which produces it. In the Corfu Channel Case evidence was admitted which had been obtained by espionage.224 Part of the key evidence in the British case had been obtained by the in- ternational equivalent of an "unreasonable search and seizure." After the mining incident of October 22, 1946, the British swept the Corfu channel in "Operation Retail" (November 1946) over the protest of Albania. Twenty-two mines were cut and two mines, which proved to be German mines of the G.Y. type, were recovered and taken to Malta. The mines appeared to have been laid a short time before the incident of 22 October. The Court admitted evidence obtained from examination of the mines and related technical details. In answer to Albania's counterclaim that the United Kingdom had violated her sovereignty in "Operation Retail," the British argued that they were securing evidence for the Court which might have been lost if the mines had been removed by Albania or had been equipped with auto- matic flooding devices. The British also argued that self help justified their action. Both arguments were rejected by the Court and the United Kingdom was held liable on the counterclaim. The evidence obtained, however, formed part of the basis for the decision of the Court that Albania was liable to the United Kingdom on the British claim. An exclusion of evidence by the Court based upon the way in which it was secured would be unrealistic in view of the known barriers established by States to the flow of information. The Court is not faced with the problem of intermittent police abuses of individuals which national constitutional guarantees are designed to minimize. The Court must get its evidence when and by whatever means it can obtain it. 223. The Oscar Chinn Case, P.C.I.J., Ser. The Court will not consent if the opposing party will have no opportunity to comment upon it or offer rebutting evidence.22 As a general propo- sition, no further documents may be submitted by a party after the close of written proceedings without consent by the other party. If the other party does not object it is presumed to consent.226 If the other party does object, the Court, after a hearing, determines whether the evidence will be admitted or excluded. If the evidence is admitted, the objecting party must have an opportunity to comment upon it and submit documents in support of its contentions. 227 If an agent or counsel refers to a document in his oral statement, he is ordinarily expected to produce it. 2 8 Production is also required if the document is to be used in the examination of witnesses. 229 Comment upon unproduced documents has created difficulty. He filed all of the documents except one and read most of them during the hearings. The Hungarian agent then objected to admission of the documents as evidence. The Court admitted all of the documents except the document whichhad not been produced. A special hearing was held to determine whether the documents should be admitted. During the hearing, the Albanian counsel, in violation of the President's instructions, gave a resume of the documents which he wished to introduce. The British agent contended that the resume was inaccurate and gave his own resume. The President reprimanded both representatives in open court.2 3 4 The Court subsequently admitted the documents. There was little else that could be done. It has been customary in contentious proceedings for the Presi- dent to announce before closing that the Court reserves the right to request the parties to furnish additional explanations or information. During its twenty-second session the Permanent Court requested an agent to submit a document. The hearing was concluded before the document was submitted. The questions then arose whether the Court could maintain the request since it could use information only after it had been communicated to the interested parties and would have to hold a hearing if a party objected. The President stated the Court would accept the document without committing himself to the pro- cedure to be followed. 2 5 The advisory proceedings present no problem as to time limitations in filing evidence, all material produced being for the information of the Court and the decision having no binding effect. (3.) Burden of Proof. The burden of proof rule applied by the Court is the simple formula of the Civil Law. The burden of proof rests upon the party which asserts the affirmative of a proposition which if not substantiated will result in a decision adverse to his contention. 20 A distinction between the burden of the risk of non-persuasion and the burden of going forward with the evidence has not been accepted by the Court. 28 7 234. 4 CORru CHANNEL CASE - PLEADINGS, ORAL ARGUMENTS, AND DOCUMENTS 305-16 (I.C.J. 1948). 235.
